comment._content: I think it might be the Richard J. "Big Dick" Butler who wrote this autobiography "Dock Walloper: The Story of "Big Dick" Butler." archive.org/details/dockwalloperstor00butlrich He was the President of the Longshoreman's Union in New York and a state assemblyman. I can't find another photo of him except the drawing in the book but it looks like it could be the same man. He was in the news in 1913 when he helped Harry Thaw escape from Matteawan State Hospital. In 1915 he was tried for conspiracy in the escape and acquitted. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70C13FE3B591673...

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: I finished reading Big Dick's book and it is really interesting. Anybody who is a fan of "Boardwalk Empire" or other early 20th century crime shows should read it as he describes all the ins and outs of crooked politicians, local government, unions, bootlegging, and saloons in New York city. He also devotes three chapters to the Harry Thaw escape and trial.
